I think it was better than anything we could have expected. It was unambiguous,

Good to see you. We have there so much we could talk about, but I think we absolutely have

Yeah. Well, look, it reminds me of something that you said on the campaign trail when you're

That's right. And again, in my view, when we talk about things like, for example,

Well, it's nice when we have good news. But as you said a few days earlier, late last week,

And all the more reason why we have to remember what's at stake in elections. Now, I think in the

I'm sensing he's Oscar in your Felix. Yeah, for him, it's the reverse. I think you know, he works

It's hugely consequential. I think the world would be a very different place right now. Of course,

Anyway, to get to your question, you know, I'm trying to be present in those campaigns and

And so I do worry about what more might be thrown at us, whether it's a national security event

And we will continue to be tested, I think, as a country.
Yeah, I had a tweet yesterday that was something in the fact that I don't invoke God very often.
But if 2020 isn't God trying to send us a message, we need to change our country.
I don't know what it is. And I didn't just mean change the presidency,
but I meant really examine the things that we have long not thought enough about in our country.
I will say, like, just to just trail back to something you said and then pose to do a question,
I was in Iowa for the steak fry, which for those of you who've never been there,

They were some of the most emotional supporters. And a lot of them had

You weren't really great at cooking a steak, but you didn't have the Biden, like, you know,

When it came to where we needed to go as a country, but it was also a chance to talk about

And so the real question is now that we're brought face to face with it in a new way,

one of the interesting things to talk about is what are the lessons that we should be taking

Yeah, there's so much to unpack there. First of all, I think that Pride is a good season to
think about ally ship. And I say that as somebody who knows that I've benefited from the involvement,
the activism of people like me and people not at all like me from the Black trans women who helped

And so I think you can't truly compare one pattern of exclusion or experience of privilege
or discrimination to another, but we can certainly learn lessons from how ally ship has made a huge
difference to the LGBTQ community and continues to. I think where we are when it comes to racial
justice is from reckoning among well-intentioned white people, including white progressives, because

discourse about racism that makes it sound like only a talked about of evil person could be capable

advantages that each of us who are white have had are directly connected to disadvantages,
the people who are black have had. It's very hard to admit that you would want to think that
because you intellectually detest racism, you're not implicated in it, but it doesn't work that way.
And so I think now's the moment and there will be I think missteps and clumsiness in the ally
ship that takes shape and that's going to have to be okay in order for us to get anywhere. I know
a lot of black leaders and friends that I speak to are expressing on one hand appreciation for
a lot of their white friends reaching out. On the other hand, I think a kind of bewilderment
in impatience of being sort of assigned the work of now educating their well-end.
It's getting us off, right. Yeah.
So we've got to do a lot of the work. Those who are on the benefiting side of any number of
privileges need to do a lot of the work to get to the other side here, even while acknowledging
and amplifying and seeing leadership from those who are on the excluded side of those same privileges.
That's right. Yeah. It's amazing how all of us can confess to being not racist and yet we live
in a racist country. So something's going on. Yeah. Someone described it as racism without
racists and that's what we've really got to come to terms with. In addition to the people who are
knowingly and proudly waving a racist flag for every one of them, there's an awful lot more
who are mixed up in racism without wanting to admit it.
Well, I learned a lesson in that I asked some of my friends how I could do a better job articulating
the issues that we're getting underrepresented in the healthcare in the Black community.
And the answer I got was, no, no, no, you don't need to articulate it. You need to listen.
And what I ended up doing was giving my Twitter platform over to Black healthcare professionals
and allow them to speak using my platform to the extent that in healthcare it reaches more people.
And to be honest, it wasn't my first instinct, it wasn't the right instinct.
I want to ask you a question that's sort of a similar vein, but it's a question my son Zach has.
I want to introduce you guys first. Zach, you want to know the lights in the window there?
Can you just say hi to Mayor Pete? How's it going? Yeah, nice to meet you. I'm doing well.
How are you? All right. Thanks. Nice to be with you. I was just wondering,
what have you learned from working across the political aisle and with people of all
different backgrounds within Indiana that you think current leadership should be invoking
more effectively to spread COVID messaging to Republicans and younger people who aren't
necessarily wearing masks and distancing? Yeah, it's a great question. And it's home for me as
somebody who is a Democrat in a very conservative state where when we were trying to get work done,
especially during my time as mayor, anything that had a strong partisan profile to it might be
dead on arrival if I was trying to get anything done with the state or get anything done across
the aisle. And so things like public health protection, especially protections to prevent
people from getting infected with a deadly disease should have nothing to do with partisan politics,
which would be nothing partisan about whether you wear a mask, there should be nothing political
about whether you comply with a stay at home order or recommendation. This should simply
be about keeping one another safe. And I think the most important thing that we can do is remember
that we're talking about complicated human nature that's capable of doing good and bad things
every day. We're capable of being proactive or being lazy. We're capable of being selfless or
selfish. Every one of us is capable of all those things. And there's a tendency in our political
language now to divide the world up into good and bad people. And so I would invite everyone to
think about one of the people you disagree with most politically. And then think about one of the

found on the campaign trail, campaigning in, for example, parts of Iowa that had voted for Barack
Obama, but then voted for Donald Trump and then voted for me, is that not everybody views the
world through this prison. And while unfortunately, we have a president who I think is really carving

Senate that I believe has become an organization that really is much more about that tribal and
partisan identity than problem solving. That doesn't speak for people of either party that
you meet every day, Republicans, Democrats, and independents. And so what I've found both as a
mayor and as a candidate is that without watering down your values or pretending to be something
or not, you can see others as human beings and try to connect on that level toward a common
purpose and a common goal by pointing to results. You know, nobody wants their loved ones to suffer.
So that's a pretty good starting point for something like this. And then we can work our way through
the things that have more of a partisan profile to them. This of all this should be so far removed
from partisan politics and political culture wars. And I think all of us need to continue finding
ways to, and I know Andy's done a great job of this, is to try to make it as factual and as
forward thinking as possible. Thank you for that. I think one of the things that both you and Vice
President Biden stood out for during the campaign, even when it was not the easy thing to do given
the nature of a primary, to say we're going to have to unify as a country. To say we're not going
